Literature Review: Particle rafts and armored droplets have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their unique properties and potential applications in various fields. These structures, formed by non-Brownian particles at fluid interfaces, exhibit complex behaviors that arise from the interplay of capillary forces, particle interactions, and interfacial deformations. This review aims to synthesize recent research on particle rafts and armored droplets, focusing on their formation, mechanical properties, and dynamic behaviors. The formation of particle rafts is primarily driven by capillary interactions between particles at fluid interfaces. Vella et al. (2004) demonstrated that these interactions can be long-ranged, extending to distances much larger than the particle size. This long-range attraction leads to the self-assembly of particles into cohesive structures, as observed by Abkarian et al. (2013) in their study of particle-covered bubbles. The strength of these capillary interactions depends on various factors, including particle size, shape, and surface properties, as well as the properties of the fluid interface. One of the key aspects of particle rafts is their mechanical behavior under different conditions. Cicuta and Vella (2009) investigated the compression of particle monolayers at liquid interfaces and found that they can exhibit both solid-like and fluid-like responses depending on the applied stress. This dual nature of particle rafts makes them particularly interesting for applications in interfacial rheology and as model systems for studying two-dimensional materials. The role of buoyancy in particle raft formation and stability has been a subject of recent investigation. Protière et al. (2017) studied the dynamics of particle clustering at air-water interfaces and observed that the rafts' own weight can play a significant role in their evolution. They found that under certain conditions, particle rafts can undergo a transition from a floating state to a sinking state, highlighting the delicate balance between capillary forces and gravitational effects. The mechanical properties of particle rafts have been extensively studied using various experimental techniques. Kassuga and Rothstein (2015) used interfacial rheology to characterize the viscoelastic properties of particle-laden interfaces and found that they can exhibit both elastic and viscous responses depending on the particle concentration and applied strain. These findings have important implications for understanding the stability and deformation of armored droplets and particle-stabilized emulsions. When subjected to external forces or large deformations, particle rafts can undergo complex structural changes. Berhanu et al. (2019) investigated the fracture patterns of particle rafts under compression and observed that the discrete nature of the particles can lead to localized failures and fragmentation. This behavior is in contrast to the continuous elastic response observed at smaller deformations, highlighting the multiscale nature of particle raft mechanics. Armored droplets, which are closely related to particle rafts, have also been the subject of intense research. These structures consist of liquid droplets covered by a protective shell of particles and exhibit unique properties that make them attractive for various applications. Aussillous and Quéré (2001) demonstrated that armored droplets can maintain non-spherical shapes due to the jamming of particles at the interface, a property that has been exploited for creating novel materials and encapsulation systems. The stability of armored droplets under dynamic conditions has been investigated by several researchers. Planchette et al. (2013) studied the impact of armored droplets on solid surfaces and observed that the particle shell can fracture upon impact, leading to the ejection of particles and partial disintegration of the droplet. This behavior has important implications for applications such as spray drying and encapsulation technologies. Recent advances in imaging techniques have provided new insights into the structure and dynamics of particle rafts and armored droplets. Horozov et al. (2005) used freeze-fracture scanning electron microscopy to visualize the arrangement of particles at liquid interfaces, revealing the complex microstructures that can form in these systems. These observations have helped to elucidate the relationship between particle-level interactions and macroscopic properties of particle-laden interfaces. Despite significant progress in understanding particle rafts and armored droplets, several open questions remain. Future research should focus on developing predictive models for the mechanical properties of these systems, exploring the role of particle shape and surface chemistry in raft formation and stability, and investigating the behavior of particle rafts and armored droplets in more complex fluid environments, such as non-Newtonian fluids or multiphase systems. In conclusion, particle rafts and armored droplets represent a fascinating class of materials that combine the properties of particulate systems with those of fluid interfaces. Their unique characteristics and potential applications make them an exciting area of research at the intersection of soft matter physics, interfacial science, and materials engineering. As our understanding of these systems continues to grow, new opportunities for their customization and application in various fields are likely to emerge.
